        }
      ]
    }
}

Callback payload samples

Callback
Content type
application/json
{
  • "action": "sign_pkcs7",
  • "signature_type": "cades",
  • "digest": "1234567890abcdef1234567890abcdef1234567890abcdef1234567890abcdef",
  • "hash_algorithm": "sha256",
  • "encoded_contents": "YmFzZSA2NCBlbmNvZGVkIGNvbnRlbnRzIG9mIHRoZSBkb2N1bWVudAo",
  • "signing_token": "custom_signing_token"
}

Refresh signatures on a document's layer

Use this endpoint to refresh LTV signatures for the given document layer.

Learn more about CAdES and LTV signatures here: https://www.nutrient.io/guides/web/signatures/digital-signatures/standards/#understanding-ltv-pades-b-lt

It will refresh the signatures with IDs provided in the signatureFQNs field. If signatureFQNs is not set, or empty, then all the signatures in the document layer will be refreshed.

path Parameters
documentId
required
string

The document ID

layerName
required
string

The layer name

header Parameters
pspdfkit-pdf-password
string
Default:
Examples:
  • password - Plain-text password
  • base64:Cg== - Base64 encoded password

The PDF document password.

The value can be either either a plain-text password or a base64 encoded password in a form base64:<encoded-password>. Use the Base64 encoding if your password contains characters that are not allowed in HTTP header or would be otherwise mangled (e.g. trailing or leading spaces)

If the document is password protected, any operations performed on it require supplying a password.

Request Body schema: application/json
signatureFQNs
Array of strings

An optional list of signature IDs to refresh.

If this list is empty then all the signatures in the document will be refreshed.

Responses

Response Schema: application/json
object

Represents a digital signature associated with a portion of the document. A signature's status is expressed via two properties:

  • integrity, which guarantees that the content covered by the signature byte-range hasn't changed since the signature has been applied.
  • validity, which guarantees that the entity who applied the signature is who they claim to be.

required
string
Enum: "ok" "tampered_document" "failed_to_retrieve_signature_contents" "failed_to_retrieve_byterange" "failed_to_compute_digest" "failed_to_retrieve_signing_certificate" "failed_to_retrieve_public_key" "failed_encryption_padding" "failed_unsupported_signature_type" "general_failure"
certificateChainValidationStatus
required
string
Enum: "ok" "ok_but_self_signed" "ok_but_could_not_check_revocation" "untrusted" "expired" "not_yet_valid" "invalid" "revoked" "failed_to_retrieve_signature_contents" "general_validation_problem"
signatureValidationStatus
required
string

isTrusted

string
ltv

Array of objects

An array of digital certificates that form the certificate chain used to validate the signature. It will contain the validated certificate chain if the signature is valid and the certificate chain could be validated. Otherwise, it will contain the certificates that were used to attempt validation.

Get Digital Signatures in a Layer

Returns a layer's digital signatures.

You can fetch the digital signature status of an individual layer using the parent document ID and the layer name.

If you use a layer name that maps to a non-existing layer, Document Engine will report the status of the document base layer without creating a new one:

path Parameters
documentId
required
string

The document ID

layerName
required
string

The layer name

header Parameters
pspdfkit-pdf-password
string
Default:
Examples:
  • password - Plain-text password
  • base64:Cg== - Base64 encoded password

The PDF document password.

The value can be either either a plain-text password or a base64 encoded password in a form base64:<encoded-password>. Use the Base64 encoding if your password contains characters that are not allowed in HTTP header or would be otherwise mangled (e.g. trailing or leading spaces)

If the document is password protected, any operations performed on it require supplying a password.

Responses

Response Schema: application/json
object
checkedAt
string <datetime>
documentModifiedSinceSignature
boolean
status
string
Enum: "valid" "warning" "error"
Array of objects
/api/documents/{documentId}/layers/{layerName}/signatures

Request samples

  • cURL
  • Node.js
  • Java
  • C#
  • Python
curl --request GET \
  --url http://localhost:5000/api/documents/{documentId}/layers/{layerName}/signatures \
  --header 'Authorization: Token token=secret' \
  --header 'pspdfkit-pdf-password: password'

Response samples

{
  • "data": {
    • "checkedAt": "string",
    • "documentModifiedSinceSignature": true,
    • "status": "valid",
    • "signatures": [
      • {
        • "signerName": "John Appleseed",
        • "creationDate": "2013-12-19 14:45:26",

        • "certificateChainValidationStatus": "ok",
        • "signatureValidationStatus": "valid",
        • "isTrusted": true,
        • "isSelfSigned": true,
        • "isExpired": true,
        • "documentModifiedSinceSignature": true,
        • "validFrom": "2023-12-01T15:34:15Z",
        • "validUntil": "2025-11-30T15:34:14Z",
        • "type": "pspdfkit/signature-info",

        • "signingCertificateChain": [
          • {
            • "isCACertificate": false,
            • "isSelfSigned": false,

            • "serialNumberHex": "1234567890ABCDEF",
            • "subjectCommonName": "John Appleseed",
            • "validFrom": "2023-12-01T15:34:15Z",
            • "validUntil": "2025-11-30T15:34:14Z",
            • "type": "pspdfkit/certificate"
            }
          ]
        }
      ]
    }
}

Redaction

Redaction is the process of removing content from a PDF page. This not only involves obscuring the content, but also removing the data in the document within the specified region.

Redaction is a two-step process:

  • First, redaction annotations are added to the layer, marking the content that should be removed.
  • Later, the redactions are applied to the layer, modifying the underlying PDF file and removing the redaction annotations permanently.

Just like any other annotation type, redaction annotations are automatically synchronized by our Instant engine, which facilitates effortless collaboration between users viewing the same layer. In addition, Nutrient Document Engine provides a set of APIs that allow users to automate the process of creating redactions and applying them.

Note that redaction is a separate component that requires a specific license. Without it, you won’t be able to import, create, or apply redactions to documents.

Working with Redaction Annotations

Redaction annotations are regular annotations, which means they can be retrieved, created, updated, and deleted with the annotation APIs.

Create Redactions

Use this endpoint to add multiple redaction annotations in a single request.

Available strategies are:

  • preset - creates redactions on top of text and annotations matching the predefined pattern. For the full list of presets, see the request schema.
  • regex - creates redactions on top of text and annotations matching the provided regular expression. The regular expressions needs to comply with the ICU regex standard.
  • text - creates redactions on top of text and annotations matching the provided string search term. Note that the search is case-insensitive.

The shape of the strategyOptions depends on the chosen strategy. Currently each strategy supports the includeAnnotations options (true by default), which controls whether redactions should also cover annotations whose content match the search query.

The user_id key allows to specify the owner of the newly created annotations, and content allows to override their visual properties.

On success, an array of created redaction annotations is returned.

path Parameters
documentId
required
string

The document ID

header Parameters
pspdfkit-pdf-password
string
Default:
Examples:
  • password - Plain-text password
  • base64:Cg== - Base64 encoded password

The PDF document password.

The value can be either either a plain-text password or a base64 encoded password in a form base64:<encoded-password>. Use the Base64 encoding if your password contains characters that are not allowed in HTTP header or would be otherwise mangled (e.g. trailing or leading spaces)

If the document is password protected, any operations performed on it require supplying a password.

Request Body schema: application/json
One of
strategy
required
string
Value: "preset"
required
object
user_id
string or null

The user identifier.

Note that Nutrient Document Engine does not provide any kind of user management and accepts any string (or null) as a valid user ID.

For records created or updated in the browser, the user_id is extracted from the JSON Web Token (JWT) used for authentication.

object

Redaction annotations determines the location of the area marked for redaction.

Responses

Response Schema: application/json
object
Array of objects
Array
createdBy
required
string or null

The user identifier.

Note that Nutrient Document Engine does not provide any kind of user management and accepts any string (or null) as a valid user ID.

For records created or updated in the browser, the user_id is extracted from the JSON Web Token (JWT) used for authentication.

updatedBy
required
string or null

The user identifier.

Note that Nutrient Document Engine does not provide any kind of user management and accepts any string (or null) as a valid user ID.

For records created or updated in the browser, the user_id is extracted from the JSON Web Token (JWT) used for authentication.

(Annotation Contents (MarkupAnnotation (object) or RedactionAnnotation (object) or TextAnnotation (object) or InkAnnotation (object) or LinkAnnotation (object) or NoteAnnotation (object) or EllipseAnnotation (object) or RectangleAnnotation (object) or LineAnnotation (object) or PolylineAnnotation (object) or PolygonAnnotation (object) or ImageAnnotation (object) or StampAnnotation (object))) or (Annotation JSON v1 (MarkupAnnotation (object) or RedactionAnnotation (object) or TextAnnotation (object) or InkAnnotation (object) or LinkAnnotation (object) or NoteAnnotation (object) or EllipseAnnotation (object) or RectangleAnnotation (object) or LineAnnotation (object) or PolylineAnnotation (object) or PolygonAnnotation (object) or ImageAnnotation (object) or StampAnnotation (object) or WidgetAnnotation (object)))
id
string

Annotation ID, unique in scope of a single Instant Layer.

group
string or null

The resource group.

Group allows to grant access to resources via Collaboration Permissions.

/api/documents/{documentId}/redactions

Request samples

  • Payload
  • cURL
  • Node.js
  • Java
  • C#
  • Python
Content type
application/json
Example
{
  • "strategy": "preset",
  • "strategyOptions": {
    • "preset": "email-address",
    • "includeAnnotations": true,
    • "start": 0,
    • "limit": null
    },
  • "user_id": "string",
  • "content": {
    • "v": 2,
    • "type": "pspdfkit/markup/redaction",
    • "pageIndex": 0,
    • "bbox": [
      • 255.10077620466092,
      • 656.7566095695641,
      • 145.91672653256705,
      • 18.390804597701162
      ],
    • "action": {
      • "type": "goTo",
      • "pageIndex": 0
      },
    • "opacity": 1,
    • "pdfObjectId": 0,
    • "id": "01DNEDPQQ22W49KDXRFPG4EPEQ",
    • "flags": [
      • "noPrint"
      ],
    • "createdAt": "2019-09-16T15:05:03.712909Z",
    • "updatedAt": "2019-09-16T15:05:03.712909Z",
    • "name": "string",
    • "creatorName": "string",
    • "customData": {
      • "foo": "bar"
      },
    • "rects": [
      • [
        • 100,
        • 200,
        • 300,
        • 400
        ]
      ],
    • "outlineColor": "#ffffff",
    • "fillColor": "^#000000$",
    • "overlayText": "CONFIDENTIAL",
    • "repeatOverlayText": true,
    • "color": "#ffffff",
    • "rotation": 0,
    • "note": "This is a note."
    }
}

  • 200
  • 422
Content type
application/json
{
  • "data": {
    • "annotations": [
      • {
        • "content": {
          • "v": 2,
          • "type": "pspdfkit/markup/highlight",
          • "pageIndex": 0,
          • "bbox": [
            • 255.10077620466092,
            • 656.7566095695641,
            • 145.91672653256705,
            • 18.390804597701162
            ],
          • "action": {
            • "type": "goTo",
            • "pageIndex": 0
            },
          • "opacity": 1,
          • "pdfObjectId": 0,
          • "id": "01DNEDPQQ22W49KDXRFPG4EPEQ",
          • "flags": [
            • "noPrint"
            ],
          • "createdAt": "2019-09-16T15:05:03.712909Z",
          • "updatedAt": "2019-09-16T15:05:03.712909Z",
          • "name": "string",
          • "creatorName": "string",
          • "customData": {
            • "foo": "bar"
            },
          • "rects": [
            • [
              • 100,
              • 200,
              • 300,
              • 400
              ]
            ],
          • "blendMode": "normal",
          • "color": "#fcee7c",
          • "note": "This is a note.",
          • "isCommentThreadRoot": true
          },
        • "id": "01DNEDPQQ22W49KDXRFPG4EPEQ",
        • "createdBy": "string",
        • "updatedBy": "string",
        • "group": "string"
        }
      ]
    }
}

Apply Redactions

Use this endpoint to apply existing redaction annotation to the default layer, erasing any content and annotations below them.

Applying redactions removes the existing redaction annotations and rewrites the underlying PDF file.

Note that regardless of applied redactions, the content and annotations from the originally uploaded file are always stored at the document's immutable base layer. In some circumstances, e.g. due to legal requirements, this may be undesirable. In these cases, you can delete the document after applying redactions, which will erase all of the document's data.

path Parameters
documentId
required
string

The document ID

header Parameters
pspdfkit-pdf-password
string
Default:
Examples:
  • password - Plain-text password
  • base64:Cg== - Base64 encoded password

The PDF document password.

The value can be either either a plain-text password or a base64 encoded password in a form base64:<encoded-password>. Use the Base64 encoding if your password contains characters that are not allowed in HTTP header or would be otherwise mangled (e.g. trailing or leading spaces)

If the document is password protected, any operations performed on it require supplying a password.

Responses

Response Schema: application/json
passwordProtected
required
boolean

Indicates whether the document is password protected.

sourcePdfSha256
required
string

SHA256 hash of the PDF file underlying the document.

title
required
string or null

The document title.

byteSize
required
integer >= 1

The size of the document in bytes.

createdAt
required
string

Date and time in ISO8601 format with timezone.

object

Information about the assert storage for the underlying PDF file.

/api/documents/{documentId}/redact

Request samples

  • cURL
  • Node.js
  • Java
  • C#
  • Python
curl --request POST \
  --url http://localhost:5000/api/documents/{documentId}/redact \
  --header 'Authorization: Token token=secret' \
  --header 'pspdfkit-pdf-password: password'

Response samples

  • 200
Content type
application/json
{
  • "passwordProtected": true,
  • "sourcePdfSha256": "1defd934dbbf77587eb9b7f45d162d2a3aea16c840a9e7cfa190fb2ea1f40a76",
  • "title": "Nutrient Document Engine API Specification",
  • "byteSize": 192000,
  • "createdAt": "2019-09-16T15:05:03.712909Z",
  • "storage": {
    • "type": "built-in",
    • "bucket": "string",
    • "url": "string"
    }
}

Create Redactions in a Layer

Use this endpoint to add multiple redaction annotations in a single request.

Available strategies are:

  • preset - creates redactions on top of text and annotations matching the predefined pattern. For the full list of presets, see the request schema.
  • regex - creates redactions on top of text and annotations matching the provided regular expression. The regular expressions needs to comply with the ICU regex standard.
  • text - creates redactions on top of text and annotations matching the provided string search term. Note that the search is case-insensitive.

The shape of the strategyOptions depends on the chosen strategy. Currently each strategy supports the includeAnnotations options (true by default), which controls whether redactions should also cover annotations whose content match the search query.

The user_id key allows to specify the owner of the newly created annotations, and content allows to override their visual properties.

On success, an array of created redaction annotations is returned.

path Parameters
documentId
required
string

The document ID

layerName
required
string

The layer name

header Parameters
pspdfkit-pdf-password
string
Default:
Examples:
  • password - Plain-text password
  • base64:Cg== - Base64 encoded password

The PDF document password.

The value can be either either a plain-text password or a base64 encoded password in a form base64:<encoded-password>. Use the Base64 encoding if your password contains characters that are not allowed in HTTP header or would be otherwise mangled (e.g. trailing or leading spaces)

If the document is password protected, any operations performed on it require supplying a password.

Request Body schema: application/json
One of
strategy
required
string
Value: "preset"
required
object
user_id
string or null

The user identifier.

Note that Nutrient Document Engine does not provide any kind of user management and accepts any string (or null) as a valid user ID.

For records created or updated in the browser, the user_id is extracted from the JSON Web Token (JWT) used for authentication.

object

Redaction annotations determines the location of the area marked for redaction.

Responses

Response Schema: application/json
object
Array of objects
Array
createdBy
required
string or null

The user identifier.

Note that Nutrient Document Engine does not provide any kind of user management and accepts any string (or null) as a valid user ID.

For records created or updated in the browser, the user_id is extracted from the JSON Web Token (JWT) used for authentication.

updatedBy
required
string or null

The user identifier.

Note that Nutrient Document Engine does not provide any kind of user management and accepts any string (or null) as a valid user ID.

For records created or updated in the browser, the user_id is extracted from the JSON Web Token (JWT) used for authentication.

(Annotation Contents (MarkupAnnotation (object) or RedactionAnnotation (object) or TextAnnotation (object) or InkAnnotation (object) or LinkAnnotation (object) or NoteAnnotation (object) or EllipseAnnotation (object) or RectangleAnnotation (object) or LineAnnotation (object) or PolylineAnnotation (object) or PolygonAnnotation (object) or ImageAnnotation (object) or StampAnnotation (object))) or (Annotation JSON v1 (MarkupAnnotation (object) or RedactionAnnotation (object) or TextAnnotation (object) or InkAnnotation (object) or LinkAnnotation (object) or NoteAnnotation (object) or EllipseAnnotation (object) or RectangleAnnotation (object) or LineAnnotation (object) or PolylineAnnotation (object) or PolygonAnnotation (object) or ImageAnnotation (object) or StampAnnotation (object) or WidgetAnnotation (object)))
id
string

Annotation ID, unique in scope of a single Instant Layer.

group
string or null

The resource group.

Group allows to grant access to resources via Collaboration Permissions.

/api/documents/{documentId}/layers/{layerName}/redactions

  • Node.js
  • Java
  • C#
  • Python
Content type
application/json
Example
{
  • "strategy": "preset",
  • "strategyOptions": {
    • "preset": "email-address",
    • "includeAnnotations": true,
    • "start": 0,
    • "limit": null
    },
  • "user_id": "string",
  • "content": {
    • "v": 2,
    • "type": "pspdfkit/markup/redaction",
    • "pageIndex": 0,
    • "bbox": [
      • 255.10077620466092,
      • 656.7566095695641,
      • 145.91672653256705,
      • 18.390804597701162
      ],
    • "action": {
      • "type": "goTo",
      • "pageIndex": 0
      },
    • "opacity": 1,
    • "pdfObjectId": 0,
    • "id": "01DNEDPQQ22W49KDXRFPG4EPEQ",
    • "flags": [
      • "noPrint"
      ],
    • "createdAt": "2019-09-16T15:05:03.712909Z",
    • "updatedAt": "2019-09-16T15:05:03.712909Z",
    • "name": "string",
    • "creatorName": "string",
    • "customData": {
      • "foo": "bar"
      },
    • "rects": [
      • [
        • 100,
        • 200,
        • 300,
        • 400
        ]
      ],
    • "outlineColor": "#ffffff",
    • "fillColor": "^#000000$",
    • "overlayText": "CONFIDENTIAL",
    • "repeatOverlayText": true,
    • "color": "#ffffff",
    • "rotation": 0,
    • "note": "This is a note."
    }
}

            • 255.10077620466092,
            • 656.7566095695641,

            • 18.390804597701162
            ],
          • "action": {

            • "pageIndex": 0
            },
          • "opacity": 1,
          • "pdfObjectId": 0,

            • "noPrint"

            • "foo": "bar"
            },

            • [
              • 100,
              • 200,
              • 300,
              • 400
              ]
            ],
          • "blendMode": "normal",
          • "color": "#fcee7c",
          • "note": "This is a note.",
          • "isCommentThreadRoot": true
          },
        • "id": "01DNEDPQQ22W49KDXRFPG4EPEQ",
        • "createdBy": "string",
        • "updatedBy": "string",
        • "group": "string"
        }
      ]
    }
}

Apply Redactions to a Layer

Use this endpoint to apply existing redaction annotation to the default layer, erasing any content and annotations below them.

Applying redactions removes the existing redaction annotations and rewrites the underlying PDF file.

Note that regardless of applied redactions, the content and annotations from the originally uploaded file are always stored at the document's immutable base layer. In some circumstances, e.g. due to legal requirements, this may be undesirable. In these cases, you can delete the document after applying redactions, which will erase all of the document's data.

path Parameters
documentId
required
string

The document ID

layerName
required
string

The layer name

header Parameters
pspdfkit-pdf-password
string
Default:
Examples:
  • password - Plain-text password
  • base64:Cg== - Base64 encoded password

The PDF document password.

The value can be either either a plain-text password or a base64 encoded password in a form base64:<encoded-password>. Use the Base64 encoding if your password contains characters that are not allowed in HTTP header or would be otherwise mangled (e.g. trailing or leading spaces)

If the document is password protected, any operations performed on it require supplying a password.

Responses

Response Schema: application/json
passwordProtected
required
boolean

Indicates whether the document is password protected.

PDF/A Validation

Validate the conformance of a PDF/A file.

Validate PDF/A Compliance

This endpoint allows you to validate the PDF/A compliance of a PDF file and returns a validation report.

header Parameters
pspdfkit-pdf-password
string
Default:
Examples:
  • password - Plain-text password
  • base64:Cg== - Base64 encoded password

The PDF document password.

The value can be either either a plain-text password or a base64 encoded password in a form base64:<encoded-password>. Use the Base64 encoding if your password contains characters that are not allowed in HTTP header or would be otherwise mangled (e.g. trailing or leading spaces)

If the document is password protected, any operations performed on it require supplying a password.

Request Body schema:

A request to validate PDF/A conformance of a document

file
string <binary>

PDF/A file on which to perform validation.

Responses

Response Schema: application/json
Conformance
string

The level of PDF/A conformance. None if PDF is non-conformant.

IsValid
boolean

true if PDF/A is conformant, false otherwise.

object
/api/validate_pdfa

Request samples

  • cURL
  • Node.js
  • Java
  • C#
  • Python
curl --request POST \
  --url http://localhost:5000/api/validate_pdfa \
  --header 'Authorization: Token token=secret' \
  --header 'content-type: multipart/form-data' \
  --header 'pspdfkit-pdf-password: password' \
  --form file=string

Response samples

  • 200
Content type
application/json
{
  • "Conformance": "string",
  • "IsValid": true,
  • "ValidationLog": {
    • "ValidationReport": {
      • "Details": {
        • "FailedChecks": {
          • "@Count": "string",
          • "Check": [
            • {
              • "@ID": "string",
              • "@OccurenceCount": "string",
              • "Occurence": {
                • "@Context": "string",
                • "@ObjReference": "string",
                • "@Statement": "string"
                }
              }
            ]
          }
        },
      • "ValidationProfile": {
        • "@Conformance": "string",
        • "@Level": "string",
        • "@Part": "string"
        },
      • "ValidationResult": {
        • "@IsCompliant": "string",
        • "@Statement": "string"
        }
      }
    }
}

Secrets

Nutrient Document Engine offers the following options for authentication:

  • Dashboard password — Used to access the Dashboard.
  • Secret keybase — Used for generating secret keys for the purposes of authentication.
  • Public key for authenticating JWT payloads — Used for client authentication.

Collectively, these options are referred to as secrets.

Managing Secrets via Environment Variables

Secrets can be configured via environmental variables. By default, current secrets are sourced from the following environmental variables:

  • JWT_PUBLIC_KEY
  • SECRET_KEY_BASE
  • DASHBOARD_PASSWORD

However, this approach has the following disadvantages:

  • You can't change secrets during runtime.
  • You can't use more than one valid secret.
  • You needed to restart Nutrient Document Engine.

Managing Secrets via API

PSPDFKit Server 2023.1.0 introduced a new mechanism for managing secrets. There’s always a “current” version of a secret that never expires. You can only change this current version using secret rotation. Next to the current version, you can have other secrets, but the non-current secrets need to have an expiration date.

To change this behavior, set REPLACE_SECRETS_FROM_ENV to false. In this case, current secrets are only sourced from environmental variables if the secrets aren’t yet set via the API. REPLACE_SECRETS_FROM_ENV must be set to false to enable secret rotation. Otherwise, secrets set via the API are replaced on every restart.

Add a Secret

Creates a new secret. This does not replace previous secrets of this type.

path Parameters
secretType
required
string
Enum: "jwt" "dashboard_password" "secret_key_base"

The Secret type

Request Body schema: application/json
required
secret
required
string

The secret value.

expiresAt
string

Date and time in ISO8601 format with timezone.

Responses

/api/secrets/{secretType}

Request samples

  • Payload
  • cURL
  • Node.js
  • Java
  • C#
  • Python
Content type
application/json
{
  • "secret": "Secret value",
  • "expiresAt": "2019-09-16T15:05:03.712909Z"
}

Gets all non-expired secret of the specified type.

path Parameters
secretType
required
string
Enum: "jwt" "dashboard_password" "secret_key_base"

The Secret type

Responses

Response Schema: application/json

id
integer

Secret's ID, unique within the specified type.

  --url http://localhost:5000/api/secrets/{secretType} \
  --header 'Authorization: Token token=secret'

    • "id": 1,
    • "expiresAt": "2019-09-16T15:05:03.712909Z"
    }
]

Rotate a Secret

Current secrets don't expire. To change current secrets, you'll need to rotate them.

path Parameters
secretType
required
string
Enum: "jwt" "dashboard_password" "secret_key_base"

The Secret type

Request Body schema: application/json
required
secret
required
string

New secret value

Responses

  • cURL
  • Node.js
  • Java
  • C#
  • Python
Content type
application/json
{
  • "secret": "New secret value"
}

Update a Secret

Updates existing secret. This is usually done to update the expiration date of existing secrets.

path Parameters

required
string
Enum: "jwt" "dashboard_password" "secret_key_base"

The Secret type

required
integer

The Secret ID

expiresAt

Maintenance

Perform general maintenance tasks.

Get the status of an async job

Get the status of a previously scheduled asynchronous job

If a job is cancelled, simply retrying the request won't help. You might need to make changes to Document Engine's configuration and restart your Document Engine instances. For example, a cancellation could occur if you attempted an asset migration job to a storage backend that's not enabled in your Document Engine configuration.

If a job is expired, then the job as well as its output assets (PDFs, images etc.) - if any, will have been deleted and thus be unavailable for download. Attempts to check the status of that job return a 404 not found error. You need to redo an expired job to regenerate those assets. You can configure the expiration time for jobs by setting the ASYNC_JOBS_TTL option in the Document Engine configuration. The default value is 2 days.

path Parameters
jobId
required
string

The async job ID

Responses

Response Schema: application/json
required
object

status indicates the state of the job. If there is more relevant information - particularly important for failed and cancelled jobs, then that information will be in details.

status
required
string
Enum: "not_started" "in_progress" "completed" "failed" "cancelled"
string or object
/api/async/jobs/{jobId}

Request samples

  • cURL
  • Node.js
  • Java
  • C#
  • Python
curl --request GET \
  --url http://localhost:5000/api/async/jobs/{jobId} \
  --header 'Authorization: Token token=secret'

Response samples

  • 200
Content type
application/json
{
  • "data": {
    • "status": "not_started",
    • "details": "string"
    }
}

Revoke JWT

This endpoint allows you to revoke JSON Web Tokens created by your service. Revoked tokens are invalided before they would normally expire. On top of preventing any future authentications with revoked JWTs, any active authenticated session is also destroyed immediately.

It's only possible to revoke JWTs with an ID that needs to be specified in their jti claim. Note that revoking a particular JWTs will revoke all JWTs with the same ID as well.

Request Body schema: application/json
required
jwts
Array of strings

Responses

Response Schema: application/json
details
string

A text summary of the status of the request

request_id
string
result
string
Enum: "partial_failure" "success" "failure"

If all the items in the batch request were successful, then the status will be a success. A partial_failure will occur if only a few of the items in the batch request succeeded. Failure is when none of the items in the batch succeed.

status
integer
Enum: 200 400 500

HTTP status code for the request. The status code is 200 if the request was processed. This does not have anything to do with the result - the status code will be 200 even if part of the request failed. In the case of total failures such as malformed JSON, or document not found, this status will be other than 200.

Array of objects

List of failing paths.

data
Array of strings

List of successfully revoked JWTs.

/api/revoke

Request samples

  • Payload
  • cURL
  • Node.js
  • Java
  • C#
  • Python
Content type
application/json
{
  • "jwts": [
    • "eyJhbGciOiJSUzI1NiIsInR5cCI6IkpXVCJ9.eyJwZXJtaXNzaW9ucyI6WyJyZWFkLWRvY3VtZW50Iiwid3JpdGUiLCJkb3dubG9hZCJdLCJkb2N1bWVudF9pZCI6IjdLUFNKTkZCVkpFNzlXR0IxM05DRzdTMlgzIiwibGF5ZXIiOiJwUUNHREVpVVFFWTdleEJfcW5zeC1BIiwiaWF0IjoxNjYwOTA4ODk0LCJleHAiOjE2NjExNjgwOTQsImp0aSI6IjU5OTAwZDVmLTIyMDgtNDNjMy1iYzk3LWMxMjgzNDI3NmM4YyJ9.BtBbivWY2cC3R_8tm1j_GxtcQFIvmGkTSsz78EXiJEsTUCkRcfZWN2lOsI0Dn2-M6sG21QSbToEhVMvL5r_4sg"
    ]
}

Response samples

  • 200
Content type
application/json
{
  • "details": "Operation was partially successful",
  • "request_id": "string",
  • "result": "partial_failure",
  • "status": 200,
  • "failingPaths": [
    • {
      • "path": "$.property[0]",
      • "details": "Missing required property"
      }
    ],
  • "data": [
    • "eyJhbGciOiJSUzI1NiIsInR5cCI6IkpXVCJ9.eyJwZXJtaXNzaW9ucyI6WyJyZWFkLWRvY3VtZW50Iiwid3JpdGUiLCJkb3dubG9hZCJdLCJkb2N1bWVudF9pZCI6IjdLUFNKTkZCVkpFNzlXR0IxM05DRzdTMlgzIiwibGF5ZXIiOiJwUUNHREVpVVFFWTdleEJfcW5zeC1BIiwiaWF0IjoxNjYwOTA4ODk0LCJleHAiOjE2NjExNjgwOTQsImp0aSI6IjU5OTAwZDVmLTIyMDgtNDNjMy1iYzk3LWMxMjgzNDI3NmM4YyJ9.BtBbivWY2cC3R_8tm1j_GxtcQFIvmGkTSsz78EXiJEsTUCkRcfZWN2lOsI0Dn2-M6sG21QSbToEhVMvL5r_4sg"
    ]
}

Fonts

Retrieve fonts and font substitutions used in the document.

Get global fonts

Responses

Response Schema: application/json
Array of objects
Array
fullName
string

A friendly name for this font face

idx
number

The index inside the font file where the font face is

fileName
string

The name of the font file that contains this font face This is the name of the file on Document Engine.

/api/fonts

Request samples

  • cURL
  • Node.js
  • Java
  • C#
  • Python
curl --request GET \
  --url http://localhost:5000/api/fonts \
  --header 'Authorization: Token token=secret'

Response samples

  • 200
Content type
application/json
{
  • "data": [
    • {
      • "fullName": "Al Bayan Bold",
      • "idx": 2,
      • "fileName": "AlBayan.ttc\""
      }
    ]
}

Get the list of font substitutions in the configured `font-substitutions.json` file, if any.

If a font-substitutions.json file has been mounted on Document Engine's container, use this endpoint to get a list of the font substitutions defined in that file,

Note that the font substitutions returned by this endpoint will be used by Document Engine when processing all documents.

Responses

Response Schema: application/json
Array of objects

A list of font substitutions.

Ordering matters - As names could match multiple patterns, we have to stress that order matters when creating or replacing font substitutions.

Array
pattern
required
string

Font family name replacements are made based upon pattern matching, allowing for a font family name to be replaced with a different name.

Patterns are matched using the following rules:

  • * matches multiple characters
  • ? matches a single character
  • Pattern and the target name are case-insensitive.
target
required
string
/api/font_substitutions

Request samples

  • cURL
  • Node.js
  • Java
  • C#
  • Python
curl --request GET \
  --url http://localhost:5000/api/font_substitutions \
  --header 'Authorization: Token token=secret'

Response samples

  • 200
Content type
application/json
{
  • "data": [
    • {
      • "pattern": "Roboto-*",
      • "target": "Courier New"
      }
    ]
}

Get fonts

path Parameters
documentId
required
string

The document ID

header Parameters
pspdfkit-pdf-password
string
Default:
Examples:
  • password - Plain-text password
  • base64:Cg== - Base64 encoded password

The PDF document password.

The value can be either either a plain-text password or a base64 encoded password in a form base64:<encoded-password>. Use the Base64 encoding if your password contains characters that are not allowed in HTTP header or would be otherwise mangled (e.g. trailing or leading spaces)

If the document is password protected, any operations performed on it require supplying a password.

Responses

Response Schema: application/json
Array of objects
Array
fullName
string

A friendly name for this font face

idx
number

The index inside the font file where the font face is

fileName
string

The name of the font file that contains this font face This is the name of the file on Document Engine.

  • cURL
  • Node.js
  • Java
  • C#
  • Python
curl --request GET \
  --url http://localhost:5000/api/documents/{documentId}/fonts \
  --header 'Authorization: Token token=secret' \
  --header 'pspdfkit-pdf-password: password'

Response samples

  • 200
Content type
application/json
{
  • "data": [
    • {
      • "fullName": "Al Bayan Bold",
      • "idx": 2,
      • "fileName": "AlBayan.ttc\""
      }
    ]
}

Get font substitutions

This endpoint allows you to get font substitutions that were set for the specific document.

Note that font substitutions returned by this endpoint will include the font substitutions defined for the specified document, as well as any font substitutions defined in the font-substitutions.json configuration file, if a font-substitutions.json file is mounted on Document Engine.

The font substitutions for the document will be merged with the font substitutions in font-substitutions.json if any, with the substitutions in the document having priority over any substitutions font-substitutions.json may define. It is this combination of font substitutions that will be applied by Document Engine when performing operations on the document where a font is unavailable and needs to be substituted.

Learn more about the font-substitutions.json file from the documentation available here: https://www.nutrient.io/guides/document-engine/configuration/custom-fonts/#font-substitutions

path Parameters
documentId
required
string

The document ID

header Parameters
pspdfkit-pdf-password
string
Default:
Examples:
  • password - Plain-text password
  • base64:Cg== - Base64 encoded password

The PDF document password.

The value can be either either a plain-text password or a base64 encoded password in a form base64:<encoded-password>. Use the Base64 encoding if your password contains characters that are not allowed in HTTP header or would be otherwise mangled (e.g. trailing or leading spaces)

If the document is password protected, any operations performed on it require supplying a password.

Responses

Response Schema: application/json
Array of objects

A list of font substitutions.

Ordering matters - As names could match multiple patterns, we have to stress that order matters when creating or replacing font substitutions.

Array
pattern
required
string

Font family name replacements are made based upon pattern matching, allowing for a font family name to be replaced with a different name.

Patterns are matched using the following rules:

  • * matches multiple characters
  • ? matches a single character
  • Pattern and the target name are case-insensitive.
target
required
string
/api/documents/{documentId}/font_substitutions

Request samples

  • cURL
  • Node.js
  • Java
  • C#
  • Python
curl --request GET \
  --url http://localhost:5000/api/documents/{documentId}/font_substitutions \
  --header 'Authorization: Token token=secret' \
  --header 'pspdfkit-pdf-password: password'

Response samples

  • 200
Content type
application/json
{
  • "data": [
    • {
      • "pattern": "Roboto-*",
      • "target": "Courier New"
      }
    ]
}

Replaces font substitutions in the document

This endpoint allows you to replace font substitutions in the document. It will delete any existing font substitutions defined for the document and replace them with these new ones

If no font substitutions existed for the document prior, it will create them.

Note that this endpoint does not affect the font substitutions specified in the font-substitutions.json configuration file, if any.

path Parameters
documentId
required
string

The document ID

header Parameters
pspdfkit-pdf-password
string
Default:
Examples:
  • password - Plain-text password
  • base64:Cg== - Base64 encoded password

The PDF document password.

The value can be either either a plain-text password or a base64 encoded password in a form base64:<encoded-password>. Use the Base64 encoding if your password contains characters that are not allowed in HTTP header or would be otherwise mangled (e.g. trailing or leading spaces)

If the document is password protected, any operations performed on it require supplying a password.

Request Body schema: application/json
required

List of font substitutions to replace the old ones with.

required
Array of objects

A list of font substitutions.

Ordering matters - As names could match multiple patterns, we have to stress that order matters when creating or replacing font substitutions.

Array
pattern
required
string

Font family name replacements are made based upon pattern matching, allowing for a font family name to be replaced with a different name.

Patterns are matched using the following rules:

  • * matches multiple characters
  • ? matches a single character
  • Pattern and the target name are case-insensitive.
target
required
string

Responses

Response Schema: application/json
details
string

A text summary of the status of the request

request_id
string
result
string
Enum: "partial_failure" "success" "failure"

If all the items in the batch request were successful, then the status will be a success. A partial_failure will occur if only a few of the items in the batch request succeeded. Failure is when none of the items in the batch succeed.

status
integer
Enum: 200 400 500

HTTP status code for the request. The status code is 200 if the request was processed. This does not have anything to do with the result - the status code will be 200 even if part of the request failed. In the case of total failures such as malformed JSON, or document not found, this status will be other than 200.

Array of objects

List of failing paths.

Array of objects

A list of font substitutions.

Ordering matters - As names could match multiple patterns, we have to stress that order matters when creating or replacing font substitutions.

/api/documents/{documentId}/font_substitutions

  • Payload
  • cURL
  • Node.js
  • Java
  • C#
  • Python
Content type
application/json
{
  • "fontSubstitutions": [
    • {
      • "pattern": "Roboto-*",
      • "target": "Courier New"
      }
    ]
}

Response samples

  • 200
  • 400
Content type
application/json
{
  • "details": "Operation was partially successful",
  • "request_id": "string",
  • "result": "partial_failure",
  • "status": 200,
  • "failingPaths": [
    • {
      • "path": "$.property[0]",
      • "details": "Missing required property"
      }
    ],
  • "data": [
    • {
      • "pattern": "Roboto-*",
      • "target": "Courier New"
      }
    ]
}

Deletes all font substitutions in the document

This endpoint allows you to delete all font substitutions in the document. Note that it won't delete other font substitutions that are associated with a different layer. To delete the font substitutions in a specific layer, make a request to the specified layer

Also note that this endpoint does not affect the font substitutions specified in the font-substitutions.json configuration file, if any.

path Parameters
documentId
required
string

The document ID

header Parameters
pspdfkit-pdf-password
string
Default:
Examples:
  • password - Plain-text password
  • base64:Cg== - Base64 encoded password

The PDF document password.

The value can be either either a plain-text password or a base64 encoded password in a form base64:<encoded-password>. Use the Base64 encoding if your password contains characters that are not allowed in HTTP header or would be otherwise mangled (e.g. trailing or leading spaces)

If the document is password protected, any operations performed on it require supplying a password.

Responses

Response Schema: application/json
details
string

A text summary of the status of the request

request_id
string
result
string
Enum: "partial_failure" "success" "failure"

If all the items in the batch request were successful, then the status will be a success. A partial_failure will occur if only a few of the items in the batch request succeeded. Failure is when none of the items in the batch succeed.

status
integer
Enum: 200 400 500

HTTP status code for the request. The status code is 200 if the request was processed. This does not have anything to do with the result - the status code will be 200 even if part of the request failed. In the case of total failures such as malformed JSON, or document not found, this status will be other than 200.

Array of objects

List of failing paths.

Array of objects

A list of font substitutions.

Ordering matters - As names could match multiple patterns, we have to stress that order matters when creating or replacing font substitutions.

Get fonts

path Parameters
documentId
required
string

The document ID

layerName
required
string

The layer name

header Parameters
pspdfkit-pdf-password
string
Default:
Examples:
  • password - Plain-text password
  • base64:Cg== - Base64 encoded password

The PDF document password.

The value can be either either a plain-text password or a base64 encoded password in a form base64:<encoded-password>. Use the Base64 encoding if your password contains characters that are not allowed in HTTP header or would be otherwise mangled (e.g. trailing or leading spaces)

If the document is password protected, any operations performed on it require supplying a password.

Responses

Response Schema: application/json
Array of objects
Array
fullName
string

A friendly name for this font face

idx
number

The index inside the font file where the font face is

fileName
string

The name of the font file that contains this font face This is the name of the file on Document Engine.

/api/documents/{documentId}/layers/{layerName}/fonts

Request samples

  • cURL
  • Node.js
  • Java
  • C#
  • Python

  --url http://localhost:5000/api/documents/{documentId}/layers/{layerName}/fonts \
  --header 'Authorization: Token token=secret' \
  --header 'pspdfkit-pdf-password: password'

Content type
application/json
{
  • "data": [
    • {
      • "fullName": "Al Bayan Bold",
      • "idx": 2,
      • "fileName": "AlBayan.ttc\""
      }
    ]
}

Get font substitutions

This endpoint allows you to get font substitutions that were set for the specific document layer.

Note that font substitutions returned by this endpoint will include the font substitutions defined for the specified document layer, as well as any font substitutions defined in the font-substitutions.json configuration file, if a font-substitutions.json file is mounted on Document Engine.

The font substitutions for the document layer will be merged with the font substitutions in font-substitutions.json if any, with the substitutions in the document layer having priority over any substitutions font-substitutions.json may define. It is this combination of font substitutions that will be applied by Document Engine when performing operations on the document layer where a font is unavailable and needs to be substituted.

Learn more about the font-substitutions.json file from the documentation available here: https://www.nutrient.io/guides/document-engine/configuration/custom-fonts/#font-substitutions

The PDF document password.

The value can be either either a plain-text password or a base64 encoded password in a form base64:<encoded-password>. Use the Base64 encoding if your password contains characters that are not allowed in HTTP header or would be otherwise mangled (e.g. trailing or leading spaces)

If the document is password protected, any operations performed on it require supplying a password.

  • ? matches a single character
  • Pattern and the target name are case-insensitive.
